import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
source.523c025c:
plt.figure(figsize=(9,9))
sns.scatterplot(x='Age', y ='EstimatedSalary', hue = 'Purchased', data=df)
plt.plot([i for i in range(62)], [df['EstimatedSalary'].mean() for j in range(62)], 'r--')
plt.plot([df['Age'].mean()for i in range(len(df['EstimatedSalary'].values))],df['EstimatedSalary'].values, 'y--')
source.1f81e732:
plt.figure(figsize=(12,12))
sns.set_style('dark')
sns.kdeplot(x=df['Age'], y=df['EstimatedSalary'], shade=True, cbar=True)
plt.scatter(x=[df['Age'].mean()],y=[df['EstimatedSalary'].mean()], c='red' )
plt.scatter(x=[df['Age'].mode()],y=[df['EstimatedSalary'].mode()], c='black' )
plt.scatter(x=[df['Age'].median()],y=[df['EstimatedSalary'].median()], c='white' )
source.809287bf:
plt.figure(figsize=(12,12))
sns.set_style('dark')
sns.kdeplot(x=df[df['Purchased']==1]['Age'], y=df[df['Purchased']==1]['EstimatedSalary'], shade=True, cbar=True)
plt.scatter(x=[df[df['Purchased']==1]['Age'].mean()],y=[df[df['Purchased']==1]['EstimatedSalary'].mean()], c='red' )
plt.scatter(x=[df[df['Purchased']==1]['Age'].mode() for j in range(4)],y=[df[df['Purchased']==1]['EstimatedSalary'].mode()], c='black' )
plt.scatter(x=[df[df['Purchased']==1]['Age'].median()],y=[df[df['Purchased']==1]['EstimatedSalary'].median()], c='white' )

source.224afed5: women in general spend a little more than men in the ads. this gap increases when the salary of the person is greater than the mean.
source.e90048ae: the estimated salary distribution in case of women is more wide than the men which has a visible peak in the range of 50000 to 1000000.
source.ff396afa: clearly it can be seen that if your salary is more than the mean of the salary data, you are more likely to but the product on seeing the ad.
source.4a0e6fb2: women with ages greater than the mean age tend to spend more on products shown in the ads, but this is just a little bit more and not some big gap.
